content.webTitle: Joe Root lauds wagging tail after digging England out of another hole

fields.headline: Joe Root lauds wagging tail after digging England out of another hole
fields.bodyText: Joe Root praised Stuart Broad and Jimmy Anderson for helping him dig England out of another hole after the sort of middle-order slump with which he became wearily familiar in Australia in the winter. Root admitted that England should have come up with better answers to India’s seamers after a ball change in mid-afternoon as six wickets tumbled for 68 runs in 21 overs on a pitch that had been the subject of so many complaints for its placidity on the first two days. “It was obviously a key part of the game,” said Root, who ended the day unbeaten on 78 from 158 balls, a return to form in the No5 spot after scores of 13 and 31 against Sri Lanka on home turf at Headingley. “The ball change played a big part and we didn’t respond to it well enough. It’s not ideal obviously; as batters we’d like to make sure we contribute more. We’re going to have to recognise those periods and front up a bit sooner. We knew our backs were against the wall and we had to fight. The way we responded after tea was fantastic. The way Stuart came out and played made it easier for me. That was a phenomenal knock, to come out and play that bravely, and at the end Jimmy was sensational.” Broad made 47 from 42 balls in an eighth-wicket stand of 78 and Root’s partnership with Anderson has so far added 54, England’s best return for the last wicket since Broad put on 61 with Darren Pattinson against South Africa at Headingley in 2008. Root confirmed that Matt Prior’s unfortunate dismissal reinforced England’s “frustration” that the decision review system has been made unavailable for the series by India. “Until the ICC make it mandatory for everyone to use it, there’s nothing we can do about it,” he said. Ishant Sharma, who started the rot in England’s middle order with a post-lunch spell of three for 29 in seven overs, suggested that India are unlikely to make a bold declaration if it carries any risk of defeat. “On these kind of wickets you can’t predict, as we have seen with the last-wicket stands,” he said. “But that’s a captaincy decision, not mine.”
